youthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: they lump all effects of climate change  (including "growing season length, net N mineralization,  N fixation" together in their reporting so it is difficult to pull out only effects of increased GSL)
ifyes_whichexternal: N deposition, climate, gsl, CO2 fertilization, disturbance (fire, harvest) "During 1895-1996, N deposition was the largest contributor to the nondisturbance effects with a total  contribution of-42%, followed by climate change at -34% and CO2 fertilization at -19% (Table 2)"
excellent_study: not excellent but interesting modelling study
big_problems: they lump all effects of climate change  (including "growing season length, net N mineralization,  N fixation" together in their reporting so it is difficult to pull out only effects of increased GSL)

species_list: Betula pubescens, Picea abies,  Pinus sylvestris(for growth)
study_scale: tree rings from cores collected from 11 different sites in high latitude and treeline locations in northern Sweden; n per species was 3,4,10, respectively)
ifyouthink_no_why: the authors say "phenological data of deciduous trees indicates that plant activity starts earlier but does not end later despite an in general later end of the thermal growing season"
big_problems: they analyzed trends in start vs end of growing season separately, and these were analyzed separately from tree ring data. If these data had been integrated in a different way, the authors could have addressed our question directly
missing_something_major: yes. they measured phenology and compared it to tree ring data, but because they 1) used different species across phenology and tree ring components; and 2) did not use raw ring widths (instead using detrended indices that were correlated with different month's temperatures, rather than growing season length)

species_list: Aesculus hippocastanum, Betula pendula, Fagus sylvativa, Larix decidua, Quercus robur, Sorbus aucuparia
study_scale: tested the degree to which timing of autumn senescence (from long-term obs data in PEP) is determined by preceding seasonal productivity (estimated from a  photosynthesis model)
study_type: continental scale long-term observational study of phenology combined with model, checked against remote-sensed data
growth_metric: photosynthesis (total growing-season net daytime photosynthesis, modelled)
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: R2, RMSE, Slope of their PIA model vs. other common models that are more focused on growing season length only
youthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure: not sure how photosynthesis relates to growth
ifyes_whichexternal: elevated carbon dioxide, temperature, light, water stress
big_problems: I'm not sure about assumptions of photosynthesis model…

growth_metric:
photosynthesis (Leaf net photosynthesis- CO2 uptake per leaf area- and cumulative seasonal 
photosynthesis rate; measured at leaf- and plant-level)
authorsthink_evidence_gslxgrowth_notsure:
I am not sure the authors would say there is NO relationship, but they question the strength of the relationship saying "spring phenology, growing-season
vapor pressure deficit, summer temperature,and precipitation affect the timing of leaf senescence indirectly, by modifying seasonal photosynthesis, whereas autumn temperature directly affects autumn phenology."
authorsthink_ALTteststatistic:: they test for relationship between photosynthesis and senescence date only (not GSL)
ifyouthink_no_why: missing SOS so can't provide evidence for growthxgsl
big_problems: no start of season or gls nmetrics- experiment ran from June 1 (shortly after all buds in all individuals had unfolded their leaves) until October 1. also they test for relationship between photosynthesis and senescence date only (not GSL)
missing_something_major: how does leaf- and plant-level photosynthesis relate to overall growth/biomass?

ifyouthink_no_why: missing SOS so can't provide evidence for growthxgsl
big_problems: they test for relationship between photosynthesis and senescence date only (not GSL)
missing_something_major: how does leaf- and plant-level photosynthesis relate to overall growth/biomass?
